title: Will India and Pakistan both attend a South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation (SAARC) summit before 1 January 2018?
preds: I doubt anything will happen in the next week.

The 20th SAARC summit is the 20th meeting of the heads of state or heads of government of the eight SAARC countries after their previous meeting in Pakistan. The Summit will take place in 2018. Yet there is no details or confirmation.

Colombo, Feb 9 (IANS) Pakistan and Sri Lanka have called for breaking a stalemate in the South Asian Association for Regional CooperaÂ­tion (Saarc), and emphasised the use of corporate and industrial ties in the region to keep the forum intact despite ongoing differences. Experts at a panel discussion, organised by the Institute of National Security Studies in Sri Lanka (INSSSL) and the Pakistan High Commission here on Wednesday, urged a dialogue to sort out differences in the region, mainly between Pakistan and India, due to which the 19th Saarc summit has not been held, Dawn news reported.

New Delhi, Islamabad on verge of full-scale conflict: Pundit

PART II - The South Asian Association for Regional Co-operation: Part Two – Where to Next?
http://www.futuredirections.org.au/publication/south-asian-association-regional-co-operation-part-two-next/

The South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation (SAARC) is the regional intergovernmental organization and geopolitical union of nations in South Asia. Its member states include Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Nepal, the Maldives, Pakistan and Sri Lanka. 
Pakistan scheduled to host the 19th summit of South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation (SAARC) in Islamabad on 9 and 10 November 2016. India including Afghanistan, Bhutan, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka and Maldives will not attend SAARC SUMMIT due to 2016 Uri attack. Pakistan postponed the SAARC summit and announced that new dates would be released soon.
Mr. Mody visited Pakistan. He has the will, or at least try to portray himself in that direction.
Tensions between the two countries are higher than in recent past. Also Mr Modi is busy in the Demonetization issue and doesn't regard SAARC as a very important treaty.

Since SAARC 2016 India does not plan to attend and their summits are on a periodical meeting only every 3 years, there is a small probability that another summit will take pleace in 2017. However, we need to take into account that the refusal of India to attend could spur interest of other member states to hold another summit soon and invite India and Pakistan together. Therefore a 1/3 of a Chance, higher than the usual asssessment.

"Pakistan assumed that it might be an Indian strategy to organize the other South Asian countries against Pakistan and ensure a regional market for Indian products, thereby consolidating and further strengthening India’s economic dominance in the region" http://www.nihcr.edu.pk/Latest_English_Journal/SAARC_Jamshed_Iqbal.pdf

Historically speaking, postpostment is not unusual for this summit. 
http://www.firstpost.com/india/saarc-summit-boycott-isnt-unprecedented-grouping-must-move-forward-without-pakistan-3025670.html

"Problem with SAARC is that some basic sort of standards of regional cooperation have to apply. If you say that I will be regional member but I will not allow regional trade, I will not allow regional connectivity, will not allow regional motor ways, I will not allow regional railways, than what is it about.
Given that the Governments on both sides have to play to their gallery, it seems highly unlikely that both will attend.
Both India and Pakistan want to display regional power and need to take part in all area meetings so they can try to show dominance.
Regional cooperation is necessary to reduce  terrorism.  If the parties can not meet the SAARC is irrelevant

Pakistan evacuates thousands from Kashmir amid escalating violence
http://edition.cnn.com/2016/11/16/asia/india-pakistan-evacuations-kashmir/
India clearly expressed its commitment to SAARC and I can hardly see them not attending if Pakistan waives its rights to host the summit if it is held somewhere else.

I believe  the chances of it happening is slightly higher than 50% , I am with Khalid on this one,
We should guesstimate with out bias !
Offcourse what will  happen in trumps world?

I don't think India will want SAARC scrapped because that will make it more difficult for them to meet Afghanistan and Maldives on a regular basis, since those two nations are not part of the alternative BIMSTEC grouping. So I expect there will be another summit in some time, but probably not in Pakistan since all the countries appear united on that front.

SAARC summits have been boycotted many times before and in one case none was held for over three years. In this particular case Pakistan will want to reschedule for Islamabad and India and the other boycott nations will not accept this. This appears to be a situation that could last for quite a while as it is not just an India/Pakistan problem but a more general issue of member states responding to Pakistan’s support of terrorism.

The South Asian Association for Regional Co-operation: Part One – The Problems of SAARC
http://www.futuredirections.org.au/publication/south-asian-association-regional-co-operation-part-one-problems-saarc/
SAARC countries lack an incentive to work together. China's One Belt One Road and the China-Pak Economic Corridor (CPEC) work at cross purposes with SAARC.
Downing my prediction to the SuperForecasting level of "Probably Not" going to happen based on Khalid comments on summit being held in Pakistan.
Not unless it is moved from Pakistan.

If the summit which was to be held in Pakistan on 9-10 November is not shifted to another country, the Indian government in its present mood is unlikely to attend. SAARC summits are meant to be held once a year, though in practice there have been 18 so far since the first one in 1985, a base rate of about 60%.

1.“There is no question of holding the Summit if four countries declare their unwillingness to participate. As the current SAARC Chair, Nepal has the responsibility of seeking a solution to such pre-Summit disputes but under the current circumstances nothing much can be attempted. We will do the due formalities and will declare the Summit of 2016 should be cancelled due to non-participation of Member States,” media quoted a Nepali diplomat.
http://www.eurasiareview.com/18102016-saarc-falling-prey-to-bilateral-disputes-analysis/
I always get India and Pakistan wrong, so don't listen to me, but I think they'll meet in the first quarter of 2017.
India and Pakistan have been doing a long and complicated dance of late.  There is another year for this question to run, which gives ample time for more choreography.

Boycotting the SAARC summit had been unprecedented, before the decision by India, followed by Bangladesh, Bhutan and Afghanistan, to not attend the 2016 summit that was supposed to be held in Pakistan in November, in response to the attacks on the Uri military base in Kashmir. As such the summit has been cancelled and no plans exist so far for a change of venue or future date. Preparation for a new summit would probably take minimum 6 months, hence the absolute earliest the summit could be held is end of year 2017. With tensions on the India-Pakistani border remaining high, it seems more likely that it will be delayed further. There has even been speculation that the cancellation marks the end of the SAARC initiative.
As a practical matter I doubt India will present itself if for no other reason the safety of the other attendees...
